CatDescriptText: Theresa Branowski, housewife, Hazelwood and Frances Dague, postmistress, Houston, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in the Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, October 15, 1960, pg. A1 with question: "Do you believe that the Pirates will lose any cash customers in 1961 because of the way the World Series tickets were..."  Mrs. Branowski's answer reads: "I think the way the tickets were handles will affect the gate next year.  It has been a case of the little man, who made the Pirates, being forgotten while the big ban took over.  You can see that in the crowds attending the World Series."  Mrs. Dague's answer reads: "No, sir.  The Pirates are not going to want for ticket buyers to their games next year with the record that the team has."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Theresa Branowski wearing coat with wide lapels and light colored gloves, standing on Smithfield Street, Downtown; Portrait of Frances Dague wearing sunglasses and button down sweater, standing on Smithfield Street, Downtown
